1. A 12-year-old female presents with progressive difficulty in walking and frequent falls over the past two years. Her parents report that she initially developed mild clumsiness around age 10, which gradually worsened to include tremors and poor coordination of her hands. She also exhibits slurred speech and difficulty swallowing, leading to occasional choking episodes. Neurological examination reveals truncal ataxia, dysmetria, and signs of peripheral neuropathy with decreased sensation in the lower limbs. Her developmental milestones were normal in early childhood, and there is no family history of neurological diseases. Brain MRI shows cerebellar atrophy without other intracranial abnormalities. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia Autosomal Recessive 5, characterized by mutations affecting cerebellar and spinal cord pathways. Supportive care including physical therapy and speech therapy has been initiated to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.
